ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic quantum mechanics terminology, angular momentum, spin, pertubation theory, simple models of potential fields
I learned about a lot of principles, theories, definitions, and important calculations in quantum mechanics, as well as methods of tackling common problems!

I gained a basic understanding of principles of quantum mechanics in one dimension and three dimensions for systems with time-independent potential energies. I also honed my skills in applicable linear algebra and integration techniques, as well as techniques related to probability theory.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Assignments are made to facilitate learning. The textbook is especially a good fit for engineering students.

Weakness: The pace of the course is not constant.

I loved the course format - the lectures were great and the supplementary videos and textbook readings were also very helpful. The course is fast-paced but rewarding, and I felt like I learned a lot and was able to delve deep into the topics despite the pace.

This course is heavily based around the Griffiths textbook, so you really, really need the book for this class. Not only is the homework assigned taken from the book, but the lectures often cover examples given in the book and don't always provide the context, so actually doing the assigned reading will seriously deepen your understanding of the material.

While I appreciated the provided printed lecture notes and the lectures being recorded, I tended to find the lectures hard to engage with live since they were taught from slides rather than being worked through in real time.

The weekly study hall with the TA was EXTREMELY helpful and I wish there could have been two rather than just one!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, highly recommended to engineering students. This is a great intro course to quantum mechanics. It is a perfect fit for engineering students with good math backgrounds.

I would recommend this highly! I had no knowledge of quantum mechanics prior to taking this class and left with a solid understanding of many concepts and topics, as well as a sparked interest in learning more! While you do cover a lot, I felt that I was able to understand the topics well and that they were accessible to me even though I had no prior experience.

I would recommend this course if you are not taking another pset-heavy class, you have a strong background in multivariable/vector calculus and linear algebra, and you are prepared to do all the reading and able to attend the TA study halls every week. Even then it will be very hard!
